member.name: T:Neo4jClient.Transactions.TransactionScopeProxy
member.summary: Represents a TransactionContext scope within an ITransactionalManager. Encapsulates the real TransactionContext, so that in reality it only exists one single TransactionContext object in a joined scope, but multiple TransactionScopeProxies that can be pushed, or popped (in a scope context).

member.name: P:Neo4jClient.Transactions.ITransaction.CustomHeaders

member.name: T:Neo4jClient.Transactions.TransactionScopeOption
member.summary: Describes the options for a transaction scope when calling ITransactionalGraphClient.BeginTransaction

member.name: T:Neo4jClient.Transactions.ITransactionalGraphClient
member.summary: Expands the capabilities of a IGraphClient interface to support a transactional model for Neo4j HTTP Cypher endpoint.

member.name: M:Neo4jClient.Transactions.ITransactionalGraphClient.BeginTransaction
member.summary: Scopes the next cypher queries within a transaction, or joins an existing one.
member.remarks:
This method should only be used when executing multiple Cypher queries in multiple HTTP requests. Neo4j already encapsulates a single Cypher request within its own transaction.
The transaction object created is thread static, that is, that the following queries will only be within a transaction for the current thread.

member.name: M:Neo4jClient.Transactions.ITransactionalGraphClient.BeginTransaction(Neo4jClient.Transactions.TransactionScopeOption)
member.summary: Scopes the next cypher queries within a transaction (or supress it), according to a given scope option.
member.remarks:
This method should be used when executing multiple Cypher queries in multiple HTTP requests, or when the thread is already under a transaction and the programmer wishes to temporarily supress it.
It should not be called to execute a single Cypher query as it will only add latency to the process. Neo4j already encapsulates a single Cypher request within its own transaction.
Be aware that joining a nested transaction must be done before the parent scope completes either by committing or rolling back, otherwise it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
The transaction object created is thread static, that is, that the following queries will only be within a transaction for the current thread.

item.description: Creates a new transaction, or joins an existing one. This the default value. The transaction commits until all the scope that have a reference to it commit. However, the transaction rolls back on the first call to Rollback().

The method will generate a new transaction. It is important to notice that this new transaction is not related to an existent parent transaction scope. Committing or rolling back either one has no effect on the other.

The statements that are executed under this scope, will not be executed under the transaction. Committing or rolling back generates an InvalidOperationException. Creating a new transaction scope with Join under a suppressed one, will be the same as RequiresNew.

member.name: P:Neo4jClient.Transactions.ITransactionalGraphClient.Transaction
member.summary: The current transaction object.
member.remarks: This object represents our current transactional scope. If it is not null, it doesn't that the code is executing under a transaction. This latter behavior can occurred when BeginTransaction() is called with TransactionScopeOption.Suppress

member.name: P:Neo4jClient.Transactions.ITransactionalGraphClient.InTransaction
member.summary: Determines if the code will be executed under a transaction.

member.name: M:Neo4jClient.Transactions.ITransactionalGraphClient.EndTransaction
member.summary: Closes the scope of a transaction. The ITransaction will behave as if it was being disposed.

member.summary: The Neo4j transaction initial transaction endpoint

member.name: P:Neo4jClient.ApiModels.RootApiResponse.Version
member.summary: Returns a structured representation of the Neo4j server version, but only with partial data. The version type (milestone, preview, release candidate, stable) is not taken in to account, so both 1.9.M01, 1.9.RC1 and 1.9.1 will all return 1.9.0.1.

member.name: T:Neo4jClient.CypherPartialResult
member.summary: This class is only used to hold partial results on the execution of a cypher query. Depending on whether we are running inside a transaction, the result string is already deserialized (because it has to be checked for errors), or we need the full HttpResponseMessage object.

member.name: T:Neo4jClient.Cypher.All
member.summary: Represents a star in a Cypher function, so All.Count() is equivalent to count(*). Only for use in return expressions like .Return(() => new { Count = All.Count() }), or start expressions like Start(new { n = All.Nodes }), but not to be called directly. (This class is just syntactic sugar for lambda expressions; there is no .NET implementation of its methods.)

member.name: M:Neo4jClient.Cypher.All.Count
member.summary: Equivalent to count(*) http://docs.neo4j.org/chunked/stable/query-aggregation.html#_count

member.name: F:Neo4jClient.Cypher.All.Nodes
member.summary: Equivalent to node(*), for use in START clauses such as Start(new { n = All.Nodes })

member.summary: Cypher 3.0 provides support for Stored Procedures via the CALL keyword.

member.summary: Cypher 3.0 no longer has the HAS() function, as it has been now superseded by EXISTS()

member.name: P:Neo4jClient.Cypher.CypherQuery.CustomHeaders
member.summary: Custom headers to add to REST calls to Neo4j server. Example usage: This can be used to provide extra information to a Neo4j Loadbalancer.

member.name: F:Neo4jClient.Cypher.CypherResultMode.Set
member.summary: In this mode, we expect the Cypher table to contain a single column. When deserializing it, instead of giving the developer a list of one-column rows, we'll just give them a list of objects. Effectively, we unwrap the column into a straight up array of entries. This is done to make the syntax a little nicer when a developer wants to return a single identity and not a full table.

member.name: F:Neo4jClient.Cypher.CypherResultMode.Projection
member.summary: This is the default mode, and tells the serializer to treat each row as one object to deserialize.

member.name: M:Neo4jClient.Cypher.CypherReturnExpressionBuilder.BuildText(System.Linq.Expressions.MemberInitExpression,Neo4jClient.Cypher.CypherCapabilities,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConverter},System.Boolean)
member.remarks:
This build method caters to object initializers, like:
new MyType { Foo = "Bar", Baz = "Qak" }
It does not however cater to anonymous types, as they don't compile down to traditional object initializers.
caters to anonymous types.

member.name: M:Neo4jClient.Cypher.CypherReturnExpressionBuilder.BuildText(System.Linq.Expressions.NewExpression,Neo4jClient.Cypher.CypherCapabilities,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConverter},System.Boolean)
member.remarks:
This C#:
new { Foo = "Bar", Baz = "Qak" }
translates to:
new __SomeAnonymousType("Bar", "Qak")
which is then a NewExpression rather than a MemberInitExpression.
This is the scenario that this build method caters for.

member.name: M:Neo4jClient.Cypher.CypherReturnExpressionBuilder.BuildText(System.Linq.Expressions.MethodCallExpression,Neo4jClient.Cypher.CypherCapabilities,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConverter})
member.remarks: This build method caters to expressions like: item => item.Count()

member.remarks: This build method caters to expressions like: item => item.As<Foo>().Bar

member.remarks:
This build method caters to object initializers, like:

It does not however cater to anonymous types, as they don't compile down to traditional object initializers.

translates to:

which is then a NewExpression rather than a MemberInitExpression.
This is the scenario that this build method caters for.

member.summary: Load a CSV into Neo4j.
member.remarks: This creates the following: LOAD CSV FROM 'fileUri' AS identifier
member.param: The file URI in the format: c:\\example.csv.
The identifier to use in the rest of the query.
Use this custom headers are defined in the CSV file
The terminator to use. If you do not define anything the Neo4j default will be used: ','
If this is null no periodic commit will be used, otherwise PERIODIC COMMIT will be added with the value set.
member.returns: An instance to continue the query with.

member.name: M:Neo4jClient.Cypher.ICypherResultItem.As``1
member.summary: Does not emit anything into the query; purely used for design-time type coersion in C#

member.name: M:Neo4jClient.Cypher.ICypherResultItem.Node``1
member.summary: DO NOT USE IN NEW CODE. Shortcut for As<Node<T>>. The general trend in both Neo4j and Cypher is moving way from returning node references. Use As<T> instead to return the information you need, without the metadata of the node. For future queries, use indexes, match expressions and well-known domain-specific data to locate the node you need rather than passing in a reference to it. (In the Neo4j 2.0 timeframe, even the START clause is starting to be deprecated in favour of MATCH and WHERE.) For updating or deleting nodes, start to use mutable Cypher instead. Clauses likE CREATE, SET and DELETE will let you do more in the same query, rather than sending extra HTTP calls over the wire for each action.
